title: Confirm Ti (Dominant)
intro: Answer based on long-term patterns across years and contexts. Use 4–5 only if it’s consistently true. Ti-dominant is self-determination through internal understanding: refining your own mental model, spotting contradictions, and becoming self-sufficient by mastering how things work.

items.text: I feel compelled to make things internally consistent. If something doesn’t make sense, I can’t fully accept it until I resolve the contradiction.
examples: I notice logical gaps/fallacies even when others don’t care.
I often pause and ask: “What exactly does that mean?”
I dislike conclusions that feel based on vague wording or shaky assumptions.
Once my model is clear, I become calm and decisive.

items.text: I naturally build my own framework for understanding a topic instead of trusting authority, tradition, or popular opinion.
examples: I don’t adopt a rule just because “experts say so” unless it makes sense to me.
I prefer to reconstruct the logic from first principles.
I’m skeptical of methods that work but can’t be explained clearly.
I often re-derive/rewire explanations in my own words.

items.text: When faced with a problem, I focus on mechanism: what is actually causing it, and what lever would fix it with minimal fuss?
examples: I troubleshoot by isolating variables and testing hypotheses.
I enjoy elegant solutions more than big emotional reassurance.
I prefer clean, simple explanations over complicated narratives.
I get energized when something becomes understandable and solvable.

items.text: I prefer handling problems independently. I trust my own analysis and dislike being forced to rely on others’ instructions.
examples: I’d rather figure it out myself than ask for help immediately.
I feel restricted when people tell me to follow steps without understanding why.
I’m fine working alone for a long time if I can focus.
I feel best when I’m competent and self-sufficient.

items.text: In conversation, I’m drawn to precise definitions and clear reasoning. I dislike vague moralizing or pressure to ‘just agree.’
examples: I ask for definitions because many arguments are word-confusion.
I dislike when people swap meanings mid-discussion.
I can be blunt if the logic is wrong, even if it’s socially awkward.
I’d rather be accurate than be comforting.

items.text: People sometimes describe me as distant, overly analytical, or hard to read—even when I feel neutral and simply focused on correctness.
examples: Others say I’m ‘cold’ when I’m actually just not emotionally activated.
I can forget to express empathy while solving the problem.
I’m sensitive to being mislabeled as arrogant when I’m just precise.
I’ve been told I overthink or get stuck on details of logic.

items.text: I rarely notice contradictions or bad reasoning, and I don’t care much if an explanation is logically tight.
examples: I prefer what feels good/works socially over what is technically correct.
I don’t like analyzing arguments; it feels unnecessary.
I often accept claims based on trust or consensus without needing clarity.
Logical precision feels like nitpicking to me.

items.text: I get easily shaken by criticism or disagreement; being challenged feels like personal invalidation more than a puzzle to solve.
examples: I take critique personally and feel hurt/embarrassed.
I avoid debate because it feels emotionally unsafe.
I need others to validate my thinking before I trust it.
I change my stance mainly to avoid conflict.

items.text: To function well, I rely heavily on routine, structure, planning systems, and external organization—not internal analysis.
examples: Without schedules/checklists, I feel lost and can’t start.
I prefer strict procedures over figuring things out.
I feel safest when everything is pre-decided and orderly.
I don’t enjoy troubleshooting; I want a known method.

items.text: I often feel confused because my emotions pull me in different directions; I struggle to stay impartial and detached from feelings.
examples: My mood strongly determines what I believe or decide.
I find it hard to separate facts from how I feel about them.
I get overwhelmed by conflicted feelings and can’t think clearly.
Emotional tension is more central than logical clarity for me.
